headline: Rays 4, Yankees 3
summary: The good news: Phil Hughes had trouble with only one Tampa Bay Rays hitter Wednesday. The bad: That hitter, Dan Johnson, hit a pair of two-run homers to hand the Yankees a 4-3 loss at Tropicana Field.

summary: Badgley Mischka presented a mix-it-up collection -- featuring sixteen gowns, wide leg trousers and a white caftan dress

summary: See the history of major U.S. benefits programs.

headline: A Helping Hand
summary: Nearly half of all Americans live in a household in which someone receives government benefits, a proportion that is now higher than at any previous time in American history. Hear from one person who has depended on these benefits, and another who disapproves.
Source: Minnesota Timberwolves

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Sept. 15, 2010

headline: Blood, Sweat and Fears
summary: "Gasland," at IFC Center, seeks an answer to the question: Why is the tap water so flammable? At BAM, "Bela Lugosi's Dead, Vampires Live Forever" is dedicated to every kind of vampire movie lurking under the full moon.

headline: Visiting Oakland, Calif.
summary: A push in recent years to revitalize the city has resulted in the opening of new restaurants and bars, housing developments, shopping centers and tourist attractions.

headline: Attorney General Race Off to Heated Start
summary: Republican Dan Donovan launched the opening salvo in the race for attorney general, calling Democratic nominee Eric Schneiderman unqualified for the job and a product of Albany dysfunction.

headline: Mets 8, Pirates 7
summary: The Mets' 8-7 come-from-behind victory over the Pirates on Wednesday night came with a cost: Rookie Jenrry Mejia, the organization's most promising pitching prospect, left the game in the third inning with what the team called an acute strain of a muscle in the back of his right shoulder.

headline: An Artful Entrepreneur Finds Comic Book Success
summary: Not a businessman by nature, Mike Richardson dubbed his venture "Dark Horse Comics." It's now the nation's third largest comics publisher.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Keeps Their Enemies Closer
summary: When Dolce & Gabbana opens its new store in Milan on Saturday, it will sell not only accessories from their main line but also items from 21 newer designers -- labels that would compete with Dolce & Gabbana in any other realm.

headline: Thieves Exploit Europe's Openness
summary: Thefts of luxury cars and heavy duty equipment are surging along Germany's eastern border. To many Germans, the reason for the increase is clear: the elimination of border controls in 2007.

headline: Enhanced Training Urged for Co-Pilots
summary: A high-level FAA advisory panel, seeking to improve cockpit safety, has called for significantly enhanced training and proficiency standards for airline co-pilots.

headline: Sprint Rules Out Quick Clearwire Buyout
summary: Sprint Nextel is unlikely to make any near-term moves to buy the remainder of Clearwire or seek control of the wireless broadband provider, its CFO said.

headline: Contract Doesn't Let Board Fire CEO
summary: Under the terms of the employment agreement for Louis Lower, the jailed chief executive of Horace Mann Educators, serving a 60-day sentence on a drunken-driving charge isn't grounds for firing—or for losing any pay.

headline: Dreamliner Test Plane Grounded on Engine Surge
summary: Boeing Co. on Wednesday said that an engine surge aboard one of its 787 Dreamliner test planes forced the company to temporarily ground the jet while it awaited a replacement engine.

headline: Air Products Fights to Move Up Annual Meeting
summary: The battle over Airgas Inc. grew more bitter Wednesday as the company sparred with hostile bidder Air Products & Chemicals Inc. over who won an important shareholder vote.

headline: Home to Contemporary Art
summary: Michael Mendelsohn and his wife, Gael, have filled their three-story town home in Hastings-on-Hudson in Westchester County with contemporary art and contemporary folk art they have collected over the past 30 years.

headline: House in Corruption Crackdown
summary: The House passed legislation that would bar companies convicted of bribing foreign officials from receiving government contracts.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: Schwarzenegger in Talks to Borrow From Calpers
summary: California finance officials are looking into whether the strapped state can borrow $2 billion from Calpers, the nation's largest pension fund.

headline: Woody Allen on Death, Love and Finances
summary: Woody Allen's new movie is about two couples, and the fortune teller who steps in to predict the direction their lives will take. John Jurgensen spoke with Allen about the film.

headline: Warren to Be Adviser on Consumer Watchdog
summary: Obama this week will name Harvard Law Professor Elizabeth Warren as a special adviser to help launch the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, according to a person familiar with the situation.

headline: Foster's Wine Could Leave Hangover
summary: Potential private-equity buyers of Foster's wine assets will need a strong head.

headline: Agent Drops Suit to End IMG-CAA Spat
summary: A sports agent who tried to break his contract with IMG Worldwide and move to CAA has dropped his lawsuit against his former employer.

headline: Alibaba and eBay: Close Frenemies?
summary: Alibaba Group and eBay are quite close these days; whether they are long-term friends or enemies remains unclear.

headline: Louisiana Sues Transocean Over Spill
summary: The state of Louisiana filed a lawsuit against Transocean, asking a federal judge to rule that it was broadly liable for damages from the Gulf oil spill.

headline: New Pricing Rules Weighed for Freight Railroads
summary: The head of the federal agency that regulates railroads said he is considering wading into a fight between shippers and freight rail companies to give farmers, coal companies and other freight customers more leverage to fight rail industry price increases.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Surge on Yen Intervention; Europe Slips
summary: Japanese stocks posted their biggest gains in more than five weeks, riding the tide of the government's intervention to support the yen, which in turn gave a boost to exporter shares.

headline: Ten-Year Treasury Drops After Yen Intervention
summary: Japan's first intervention in six years to rein in the yen's gain boosted demand for short-dated Treasurys while weakening long-dated securities for the first time this week.

headline: Forest Labs to Pay $313 Million Penalty
summary: Forest Labs agreed to pay $313 million to settle criminal and civil charges that it improperly marketed antidepressants and distributed an unapproved thyroid drug.

headline: Japan's Yen Move Is Quick Fix
summary: Tokyo's currency intervention was an attempt to apply short-term emergency treatment to deteriorating economic conditions.

headline: Japanese Government Bonds Keep Rising
summary: Japanese government-bond futures ended sharply higher, shrugging off the government's efforts to curb the yen's rise. Investors continued to respond to the defeat of Ichiro Ozawa, who had made it clear he would spend heavily to revive the economy, in an election for the top job in the governing Democratic Party of Japan.

headline: Dollar Rises; More Intervention Awaited
summary: The dollar strengthened against the yen after Japan intervened in the markets to weaken its currency for the first time in more than six years.

headline: Hayward Faults Complacency
summary: BP's outgoing CEO Hayward defended the company's safety record before a British parliamentary committee and said the Gulf spill reflected complacency in the oil industry rather than problems specific to BP.

headline: Advisers Decamp Goldman for Credit Suisse
summary: A team of high-producing financial advisers left Goldman Sachs Group to join Credit Suisse Group's U.S. private-banking unit.

headline: China Monitors BHP's Potash Bid
summary: China said it is watching BHP's bid for Canada's Potash Corp., making Beijing's first official comments about the proposed acquisition.

headline: Ayotte Wins New Hampshire GOP Senate Race
summary: Former Attorney General Kelly Ayotte, the choice of the Republican establishment in New Hampshire, won her party's Senate nomination, fending off three challengers and a national anti-establishment mood.

headline: Blue Chips Gain 46.24
summary: The Dow industrials rose 46.24 points, or 0.44%, to 10572.73, after a package of mixed economic data and Japan's move to tame the yen.

headline: Crude Cuts Losses After Supply Data
summary: Crude-oil futures remained weak, but were above earlier lows, after weekly U.S. oil inventory data showed a modest drop in stockpiles.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Gold Slips Below Its Record
summary: Gold futures traded lower as some sold holdings to cash in on the metal's record-high prices.

headline: Southwest Flight Attendants Back 737-800
summary: Southwest Airlines Co. said it moved a step closer toward possibly adding Boeing Co.'s 737-800 aircraft to its fleet as its flight attendants union unanimously approved a tentative agreement regarding the matter.

headline: DuPont's Pioneer Hi-Bred Looks to Grow in Africa
summary: The head of E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co.'s agribusiness division said Wednesday that a deal to purchase a majority stake in South Africa-based Pannar Seed Ltd. will expand the company's footprint in sub-Saharan Africa and is key to increasing global food output.

headline: Las Vegas Sands Stresses Unit's Independence
summary: Las Vegas Sands Chairman Sheldon Adelson stressed the independence of the company's Macau operations, saying the U.S.-listed company isn't trying to cannibalize the unit's profits.

headline: Exporters Welcome Yen Move
summary: Japan's leading exporters, having complained about the yen's strength for months, cautiously welcomed the government's currency intervention—though for many it won't be enough to help this year's bottom line reach expectations.

headline: European Markets Slip
summary: European stock markets retreated, but finished off their lows with a solid U.S. session providing support. The yen fell sharply after Japan intervened in the currency markets by selling yen.

headline: Toyota's Scion Counts on New Models
summary: Toyota's youth-oriented Scion brand is counting on the launch of two U.S. models in the next seven months to halt a deep slump in sales.

headline: BOE's King Tries to Sell Unions on Cuts
summary: Bank of England Governor Mervyn King sought to win labor unions' understanding of the need for painful fiscal austerity, stressing that radical action is vital to reassure investors and to achieve sustainable economic growth.

headline: Anti-American Protest in Kabul
summary: One of the largest anti-American protests in years turned deadly in Kabul Wednesday, with as many as five protesters reported shot dead by police and a neighborhood shut down by rioting.

headline: Euro-Zone Inflation Slips
summary: The euro zone's annual inflation rate dipped in August, indicating the ECB has ample room to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy.

headline: U.K. Jobless Claims Rise
summary: U.K. claimant-count unemployment rose in August for the first time since January, hinting at tough times ahead once government spending cuts begin to bite.

headline: Paladino Sends Lazio to Sidelines
summary: Carl Paladino toppled the GOP's favored gubernatorial candidate, an upset that clears the way for what he promised would be a bare-knuckled effort to derail Cuomo in November.

headline: Bain Boosts Stake in GOME
summary: Bain Capital increased its stake in  GOME Electrical Appliances Holdings to 10%, diluting the holdings of the company's jailed founder.

headline: AngloGold to Raise Capital, Unwind Gold Hedge
summary: AngloGold plans to raise about $1.37 billion to get rid of forward gold sales contracts that are weighing on its earnings, a bet on continued high gold prices.

headline: Tokyo Stocks Surge on Yen Intervention
summary: Japanese stocks posted their biggest gains in more than five weeks, riding the tide of the government's intervention to support the yen, which in turn gave a major boost to exporter shares.

headline: Beazer Warns of Order Miss
summary: Beazer Homes said it might miss order expectations for its fiscal-fourth quarter and also cut estimates for the year's land and development spending.

headline: Economy Helps Sweden's Reinfeldt Ahead of Election
summary: Swedish Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt heads into Sunday's general election on the crest of the sharpest economic recovery among Europe's major countries.

headline: Fashion Meets Real Estate
summary: Faced with the challenge of selling a 19-Century townhouse in Harlem offered for $1.685 million, broker Lana Turner is using a fashion exhibition of her vintage wardrobe to draw potential buyers. Here's a look inside the home.

headline: First Quantum Sues ENRC Over Congo Mine
summary: First Quantum Minerals started legal proceedings against four subsidiaries of Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation in the latest twist in its dispute over a Congolese copper project.

headline: Gramercy Deco Co-Op
summary: The owner of this Manhattan co-op found decorating inspiration in a stay in a Miami Art Deco hotel and an exhibit of a legendary designer's works.

headline: Foreign Investment in China Slows
summary: Growth in foreign direct investment in China slowed sharply for the second consecutive month in August but some economists said monthly fluctuations don't reflect the overall trend.

headline: Tea Party Names on the Ballot
summary: See some of the candidates endorsed by the tea-party movement.

headline: H-P to Buy ArcSight for $1.5 Billion
summary: Hewlett-Packard Co. agreed to buy security-software maker ArcSight Inc. for about $1.5 billion, continuing the company's spending spree that began after Chief Executive Mark Hurd resigned last month.

headline: Tata Motors Global Vehicle Sales Up 29%
summary: Tata Motors posted a 29% rise in global automobile sales in August as demand for Jaguar and Land Rover luxury vehicles expanded worldwide and it sold more trucks and buses in its home market of India.

headline: India Official: No Information on Barring China in Oil, Gas Auction
summary: India's oil ministry isn't aware of any federal government decision to bar China, Pakistan and Bangladesh from bidding for oil and gas blocks, a senior official said.

headline: India Body: Protectionist Trends in U.S. "Disturbing"
summary: India's information technology industry doesn't expect any immediate impact from protectionist steps being considered in the U.S. against outsourcing information technology services, but sees the trend as "disturbing."

headline: PVR May Revive DT Cinemas Acquisition Talks
summary: PVR is exploring the possibility of reviving talks to acquire DT Cinemas, owned by real estate major DLF Group, as it seeks to expand in India's fast-growing movie market, the cinema theater operator's president said.

headline: Next's Net Profit Climbs 17.6%
summary: Next said cost-cutting helped lift its first-half net profit 17.6%, but the retailer warned that the consumer environment may stay sluggish for some time.

headline: Singapore Considers Intervening
summary: Singapore's central bank could intervene to bring down the Singaporean dollar for the second time in a month if the currency rises to S$1.33 to the U.S. dollar; Thailand's central bank says it has no plans to curb the baht's rise.

headline: India August Exports Up 22%
summary: India's merchandise exports rose 22% from a year earlier to $16.64 billion in August, trade secretary Rahul Khullar said.

headline: On Japan's Trading Floors
summary: The Japanese government said it jumped into currency markets for the first time in more than six years Wednesday morning, intervening to try to stem the yen's sharp rise. See reaction on trading floors.

headline: U.K. Inflation Holds Steady
summary: U.K. consumer-price inflation remained at least a percentage point above the Bank of England's target for the eighth consecutive month in August, boosted by airfares, clothing and food prices.

headline: Thai Airways Prices New Shares at Discount
summary: Thai Airways said its offer of new shares, targeted to raise $487 million in fresh funds, has been priced at a cheaper per-share level than what the market expected.

headline: Maloney, Rangel Win Primaries
summary: Veteran lawmakers Carolyn Maloney and Charles Rangel beat back tough challenges in Tuesday's primary, racking up big victories over rivals who challenged their longstanding dominance in their Manhattan districts.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Sept. 15, 2010

headline: Terra Firma Suit Against Citigroup Can Go Ahead
summary: A lawsuit by Terra Firma Capital Partners against Citigroup over Terra Firma's deal to acquire EMI Group in 2007 will go to trial, ruled a U.S. judge.

headline: Will Uncle Sam Buy?
summary: Treasury prices rallied despite better data as investors remained concerned about the long-term health of the economy and swept up low-risk debt.

headline: U.S. Hiker Departs Iran Free on Bail
summary: A Tehran prosecutor said Sarah Shourd, one of three Americans held on espionage charges, has been freed on bail and turned over to Swiss diplomats.

headline: Patient-Physician Autonomy Comes With Your Payment
summary: Regarding Saul Greenfield's "In Defense of Physician Autonomy" (op-ed, Sept. 7): If physicians and patients wish that a third party pay for their treatment decisions, physicians should be prepared to justify these decisions to the third party payer with appeal to robust, scientifically validated evidence

headline: Bjorn Lomborg: U-Turn On Global Warming? Hardly.
summary: Being skeptical of Al Gore's solution doesn't make me a 'denier.'

summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Traders Buy In to Moynihan's Plan for BofA
summary: Investors behind the day's most notable options trade bet that Bank of America's stock can stage double-digit percentage gains this autumn.

headline: Browsers Get a Face-Lift
summary: Microsoft and other makers of browsers are preparing for a significant technology shift, which industry executives say could have a major impact on the creation and appearance of many websites.

headline: Smoking Ban Plan Extends to Parks
summary: Mayor Michael Bloomberg plans to propose banning smoking on New York City beaches and in city parks, marking a significant reversal in his stance from earlier this year.

headline: CEO Convicted of Insider Trading
summary: The founder of a body-armor maker was convicted on insider trading and other charges in a more-than $190 million alleged scheme to misappropriate millions of dollars in corporate funds for his own use.

headline: New Leadership for Warner
summary: In a management shake-up at one of the nation's biggest music labels, Tom Whalley, chairman and chief executive of Warner Bros. Records, is departing after nine years on the job.

headline: Cisco to Start Paying Dividend
summary: Cisco plans to start paying a dividend before the end of its current fiscal year, becoming the latest technology behemoth to start returning cash to shareholders as the companies have matured.

headline: Private Equity's Public Struggle
summary: As buyout shops rush to the IPO market, they may be forced to accept lower valuations for portfolio companies and make it tougher for other firms to raise money.

headline: Berlin's Wertheim Site to Rise Anew
summary: After years of delays and legal disputes, construction of a retail, hotel and residential complex on the former site of Berlin's iconic Wertheim department store on Leipziger Platz is set to begin.

headline: Obama's Outsourced Trade Policy
summary: Is the Administration in charge, or are the United Steelworkers?

headline: A Garment's Path From Runway to Retail
summary: How do extreme runway looks become clothes you would actually wear? The journey of one bodysuit from Donna Karan International tells the tale.

headline: Turkey's Economy Grows 10.3%
summary: Turkey's economy grew by 10.3% in the second quarter, underlining a rapid recovery that economists say will also get a boost from firm support for constitutional reforms.

headline: SEIU Should InvestIn the Private Sector
summary: Elesio Medina (The SEIU vs. Gov. Schwarzenegger, Letters, Sept. 9) wants Service Employees International Union members to have guaranteed retirement incomes at levels higher than available in the private sector.

headline: Stone Energy Declines 3%; Horace Mann Edges Lower
summary: Small-capitalization stocks slipped, weighed by energy companies as uncertainty over the shutdown of a major pipeline put pressure on crude-oil prices.

headline: Australia Ups Wheat Forecast
summary: Australia will produce substantially more wheat than expected from winter crops, potentially adding to supply in a strained global market and to the nation's export revenue.

headline: Celebrities, Brokers Trade for Charity
summary: Actors and athletes help Cantor Fitzgerald affiliates world-wide raise $13 million for 75 charities.

headline: Army Tests Digital Command Posts
summary: In a remote stretch of desert in southeastern New Mexico, the U.S. Army is experimenting with gadgetry that may play a key role in the battlefields of the not-too-distant future.

headline: Federal Pay Still Inflated After Accounting for Skills
summary: From the Heritage FoundationFederal employees are paid substantially more than comparably skilled private sector workers.

headline: Real-Estate Slump Could Impede Korea
summary: South Korea recovered quickly from the global economic downturn, but the country now is experiencing a slump in real estate that economists say could restrain growth.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Sept. 15, 2010

headline: Ravens Deal Jets a Hard Knock
summary: The big-talking, championship-guaranteeing Jets lost their pressured-packed season opener to the Baltimore Ravens, 10-9.

headline: Safe and Risky Bets Beat the Dollar
summary: The dollar slumped broadly, hitting a 15-year low against the yen, a series of one-month lows against the euro and dipping below parity against the Swiss franc.

headline: Israeli, Palestinian Leaders Meet
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas entered into "detailed" discussions on the foundations for creating an independent Palestinian state.

headline: The Reign in Spain
summary: Throughout this summer, the world's biggest sporting events have ended in similar fashion: With a grinning athlete, draped in the Spanish flag, jumping up and down with the trophy.

headline: The Other Big Show: Toronto Film Festival
summary: While everyone has been at New York Fashion Week, pretty much everyone else has been at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Isn't the Rule, First Do No Harm?
summary: The fact that proposed rate increases for health insurance will mostly be borne by individuals and small-business employees simply adds insult to injury ("Health Insurers Plan Hikes," page one, Sept. 8).

headline: Losing Hair for No Reason
summary: Ralph Gardner discusses how a barber is akin to your signature aftershave or cologne. You don't give it a second thought until it's discontinued, and then you panic. It's as if part of you has been discontinued, too.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: When the European Cup was relaunched as the Champions League in the early 1990s, UEFA executives probably had something like this year's Group G fixtures in mind.

headline: Plans Form for Local Afghan Police
summary: U.S. and NATO commanders across Afghanistan are preparing plans for village-based defense forces that will receive arms and funds in a bid to beat back Taliban insurgents in rural towns where Karzai's government has scant control.

headline: No Wonder Government Employee Unions Are Powerful
summary: There is an easier explanation than Amity Shlaes's description of "How Government Unions Became so Powerful" (op-ed, Sept. 4): It's simply that for many years, government employee contracts have been effectively written by elected officials who cannot see much past the next election, and by union representatives, both negotiating with taxpayers' money.

headline: IBM CEO Thumps H-P
summary: IBM CEO Samuel Palmisano criticized rival H-P's decision to spend heavily to acquire 3PAR and pay a hefty severance to former CEO Mark Hurd.

headline: When Your Season Is Over After Week 1
summary: Packers running back Ryan Grant and Jets nose tackle Kris Jenkins are gone for the year; elsewhere, the NFL players' union launches a new website, and a new shield that fits over a headset microphone.

headline: Kabul Protest Turns Deadly
summary: One of the largest anti-American protests in years turned deadly in Kabul, with as many as five protesters reported shot dead by police and a neighborhood shut down by rioting.

headline: Felix G. Rohatyn: The Case for an Infrastructure Bank
summary: We need projects that meet national economic objectives, not local political ones.

headline: EU Draft Rules Target Short Selling
summary: New EU proposals are set to emerge aimed at regulating financial practices that were blamed for intensifying the global financial crisis, including the short selling of securities.

headline: Bill Would Repeal Military Gay Law
summary: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D., Nev.) is pushing ahead with a measure that would repeal the Pentagon's ban on gays and lesbians serving openly in the military.

headline: Citi Names Credit-Card Chief
summary: Citigroup has hired Jud Linville to be chief executive of its credit-card business.

headline: President Could Use His Own Advice
summary: Regarding Daniel Henninger's A President's Class War" (Wonder land, Sept. 9): I was struck by the contrast in Mr. Obama's own rhetoric and what he enjoined other world leaders to do in his press conference this morning.

headline: Kroger Profit Rises, as Prices Slip
summary: Kroger overcame falling prices for many grocery items—typically a harsh  climate for supermarkets—to post a 2.8% rise in fiscal second-quarter profits Tuesday.

headline: Pope's Offer Colors First U.K. Visit
summary: As Pope Benedict XVI arrives for his visit to the U.K., his recruitment offer hasn't resonated widely with Anglicans, officials in both churches say.

headline: Anglo Moves as Markets Turn Yellow
summary: AngloGold Ashanti's plan to sell about $850 million of stock and use the proceeds to buy out its remaining gold hedges marks the end of an era.

headline: U.S. Firm Strikes China Card Deal
summary: Global Payments said it struck a deal to process card payments in China denominated in the local currency, a small opening in a potentially lucrative part of China's financial market.

headline: Brands Recover, Despite Some Casualties
summary: The value of the top 100 global brands rose by a collective 4% this year,  with Coca-Cola retaining the No.1  slot, but public-relations debacles took a toll on the value of the BP and Toyota brands.

headline: Where American Dreams Went to Drink
summary: Half a century after its creation, Lionel Rogosin's "On the Bowery" remains a quintessential document of old New York.

headline: Sweetener Wants New Name
summary: Makers of high fructose corn syrup, a much maligned but ubiquitous packaged-food ingredient, are asking regulators for permission to use the name "corn sugar."

summary: New York Democratic congressman Charles Rangel won a primary contest that tested his ability to overcome ethics charges that have made him a pariah to many in his own party.

headline: Foreign Banks in China  See Profits Lag Behind
summary: Earnings plunged last year at foreign banks operating in China even as their Chinese counterparts posted double-digit gains, illustrating the challenges in a market many see as a driver of growth.

headline: Pavement, and Other Solid Things
summary: Pavement comes to Brooklyn, Athens, Ga.-based Of Montreal features Janelle Monae, and Strung Out plays at the Gramercy Theatre.

headline: IPad's E-Reading Apps
summary: The iPad offers a wide selection of different e-reading apps. None is substantially better than the other, but together they enhance the experience of reading e-books.

headline: Senate Tax Showdown
summary: Five Democrats have already said no.

summary: Responding to "Will Brussels Boycott De Gucht?" (editorial, Sept. 7).

headline: Jasper Kim: Riding Korea's Property Waves
summary: Policy makers struggle to find the line between "market" and "bubble."

summary: Robert Moran, a director at Collective Brands, recently bought 40,000 company shares, a purchase that stands out because of another transaction the same day.

headline: Air Freight a Window Into FedEx
summary: Strong results from the shipping company should help to quiet recession fears. But the company still has to contend with the 'trade-down' effect.

summary: Chevron is close to a deal with China National Petroleum to import natural gas from Australia, in the industry's latest bet that demand from China will justify multibillion-dollar projects aimed at tapping new gas supplies.

headline: Designers Show Free at Downtown Studio
summary: A program by Mac Cosmetics and Milk Studios lets designers mount fashion shows—free.

summary: Recently renovated for use as an upscale retreat, Nautilus Island boasts restored 18th- and 19th-century buildings. Vegetable gardens and pastures keep the 37-acre property self-sustaining.

summary: The TV host has a point when he says a limitless view of state power is un-American.

headline: GTIS Makes Raw-Land Bet
summary: GTIS Partners, a New York private-equity firm, has acquired nearly 2,200 home sites in Texas and Florida on the cheap as part of a splurge on raw land that began in March.

headline: Sri Lanka's Peace-Torn Democracy
summary: In consolidating power, President Rajapaksa risks squandering one of his country's greatest advantages.
